content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Check out the NHL Standings 2023-24 on ESPN to see which teams are at the top and which are at the bottom in Eastern and Western Conference. What about the situation in Division.  Please interact with https://www.espn.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open ESPN search bar to search for NHL standings. Click the search button.
Action: Click [4353]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Search textbox is focused; enter query "NHL standings 2023-24".
Action: Type [6]; NHL standings 2023-24
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate a result linking to the NHL 2023‑24 standings page; scroll the results list down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Faster to open Google search to locate ESPN NHL standings page then capture info.
Action: Google
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Enter Google query "ESPN NHL standings 2023‑24".
Action: Type [1]; ESPN NHL standings 2023-24
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google blocked with captcha; better to return to ESPN search page and locate standings link.
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to return to ESPN page to navigate to NHL standings information, so go back.
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Want to open the ESPN “Sports” menu to choose NHL and navigate to its standings page.
Action: Click [7]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to browse further down the ESPN search results to find the actual NHL standings page (not articles). Scrolling the window will reveal additional result sections like “STANDINGS”.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to view “Top Results” tab; click the link to load it.
Action: Click [3032]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Want to see more results in Top Results, likely below Articles. Scroll down the page to load further sections such as Standings.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: More reliable path: open ESPN’s main navigation menu to pick NHL and then select Standings page.
Action: Click [11]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The navigation menu is open; click the “NHL” link to go to the NHL section where the Standings option will be available.
Action: Click [5881]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Navigate to the NHL standings page using the “Standings” link in the NHL navigation bar.
Action: Click [7606]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to switch from the default 2024‑25 standings to the required 2023‑24 season. Open the “Standings Season” drop‑down.
Action: Click [10342]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The Standings Season drop‑down is expanded, but the season options (e.g., “2023‑24”) aren’t yet visible in the current tree segment. Scrolling the window upward should bring the options into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to bring season options into view; try scrolling window downward to reveal the dropdown list.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to bring the Standings Season dropdown (with 2023‑24 option) back into view near the top of the standings tables; scroll the window upward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Standings Season” dropdown (10342) is currently collapsed; click it to open the list of available seasons so I can select 2023‑24.
Action: Click [10342]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The season list for the now‑expanded “Standings Season” combo box is not visible in the current tree; scrolling the window down a bit should bring the list options (e.g., 2023‑24) into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The option list for the Standings Season dropdown is likely positioned near the combobox, which sits just above the conference tables. Scrolling the window upward should bring the list of seasons (including 2023‑24) into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Standings Season” dropdown (10342) is collapsed; click it to open the list of seasons and look for 2023‑24.
Action: Click [10342]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The season list from the expanded “Standings Season” combo box may be rendered just below it but outside the current viewport; a small downward scroll could bring the season options (including 2023‑24) into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)
ANSWER;
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Click [10342]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
